==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|s=鸟}}
[[File:Harpyhaliaetus coronatus.jpg|thumb|240px]]

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etyl}}
{{liushu|p}}: a bird with a dangling tail.

Compare {{zh-l|*烏}}, which is very similar, of similar origin, and {{zh-l|*隹}}, which originated from a similar image of a bird, but is today rather more abstract and less recognizable.

Compare also {{zh-l|*馬|horse}}, whose current form is similar (graphically, {{zh-l|*灬}} for claws/legs).

===Etymology===
Originally pronounced with a {{IPAchar|/t-/}} initial (compare {{och-l|島|island}}). In many dialects, it changed to a {{IPAchar|/n-/}} initial to avoid homophony with the vulgar word {{zh-l|屌|penis}}, which may have developed from the sense “bird” eventually. Birds/fowl are characteristically associated with Chinese slangs for genitalia; compare {{zh-l|*雀|sparrow > penis}} and {{zh-l|*雞|chicken > penis}}.

Alternatively, {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} hypothesised that the {{IPAchar|/n-/}} initial form for “bird” may be unrelated to the {{IPAchar|/t-/}} form. Instead, it may be connected with the Tai-Kadai word for bird; confer {{cog|tai-pro|*C̬.nokᴰ||bird}}, whence {{cog|th|นก}}.

The {{IPAchar|/t-/}} form may be derived from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*daw||bird}}, cognate with Proto-Karen *''thoᴮ'' (“bird”) and Proto-Bodo-Garo *''daw/dow'' (“bird”).

===Etymology===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
{{wikipedia|Bird}}
[[File:Bird_Diversity_2011.png|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|鳥}} (''tori''): various kinds of '''[[bird]]s'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|とり|yomi=k}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=とり}}. Probably cognate with {{etyl|okm|-}} {{m|ko|ᄃᆞᆰ|tr=tolk}}, modern {{cog|ko|닭||fowl; chicken}}.

May also be related to the {{etyl|ja|-}} verb {{m|ja|飛ぶ|tr=tobu||to fly}}.
